Wandering loanword = Wanderwort â‹
Cultural trade word = Kulturwort

Wanderwort

Â«A word that was spread among numerous languages and cultures, usually
in connection with trade, so that it becomes impossible to establish its
original etymology, or even its original language.Â»
-- Wikipedia 18 Febr. 2007

Wonderwards ;) PSM

Due to it's 3000 year prevalence, Egyptian was central in the distribution of Wanderwords.
In fact most known ancient Wanderwords have a representative in the Egyptian language, and many words in the Egyptian language are themselves super-regional words, connected to wide-spread and well known word-clusters.

Wandersigns

Wandersigns are wanderworts with near identical phonetic value that are connected to near identical stable signs.

Theses astonishing clusters can probably be explained by the advent and spread of syllabic writing, where some signs were adopted and learned as axioms even when they were foreign to local languages, one academic example being ğ”’´ nu â‰ˆ ğœœ nu â‰ˆ ğŠµ N â‰ˆ ğ€› ni ğ˜ NI Î½Î¹ÎºÏÎ»ÎµÎ¿Î½ "fig" of unknown origin.

By far the best examples in the history of syllabic writing are:

ğ’†³ kur ğ’†  ki ğ”—œ ku ğœº KU ğ˜¾ ka ğ€ KA ğ‘£ ĞºĞµÑ€Ğ»Ğ° ğ”•† â€¢KAR ğ”•ˆ KA ğ”•‡ ğ€¤ ğ˜¿ QE ğ’‰½ KURâ‚‚ ğ’„¯ á¸ªar ğ“Š– [1]
ğœ°¸ ğ“Š– ğœ°´ ğ’†  KAR KIÊ³ IDENTICAL continuum in Indus Valley Harappan script !!!
The surface features Kreuz and Kreis (cross and circle) or Kreuz and Karos (cross and squares) only reveal the underlying wanderword(s) to ones familiar with the script: In at least three instances of remote regions Egypt, Elam, Sumer, Indus and Anatolia these signs mean "city" or country. See KAR for exhaustive discussion.

ğ“ˆ— MAR wanderword ğ’ˆ¨ğ’Šğ’‰¡ me-ra-nu "bitter" @ marine Õ´Õ¼Õ¸Ö‚ má¹™uâ¿ áˆ˜áˆ«áˆ« mÃ¤rara ğğ— mr Ù…ÙØ±Ù‘ murr mÃ¼rr amargu amur amuor marcus mÃµru ğ’ˆ¨ğ’Šğ’‰¡ me-ra-nu amaráµ’â¿ amÄrus@Latin ×Ö·×¨ mar ××¨×” marÃ¡ ×Ö¸×¨Ö´×™×¨ marÃ­r ××¨×™×¨×” amargo áƒ›áƒ¬áƒáƒ áƒ” mcÌ£are ! àº‚àº»àº¡ khom? mapait?

"One of the characteristics of these
modern wandering words is that we can observe them rapidly spreading
across Europe and beyond, and through many languages. They have had
little time to undergo language-specific developments, and this is why the
precise route of their wanderings is sometimes so difficult to trace: we
have no sound-laws to guide us."

Later products, Wanderworts after the pharaos
ginger
cumin
soap
meter (maÃŸ)
green tea (not yet)

mine ğğ mn Î¼Î½á¾¶ mina Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’Ø¬ÙÙ… manjam

An alternative denomination for these kinds of words is
internationalisms, although some prefer to reserve the latter term for
technical innovations from the 19 th and 20 th century only, such as
telephone, automobile and computer.

Suggested measurements:

Wanderworthyness shall be a weighted sum of these sub-heuristics:

Percentage of main word usage near identical (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of main word usage simmilar (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of main word usage traceable (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of secondary word usage near identical (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of secondary word usage simmilar (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of secondary word usage traceable (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of related words near identical (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of related words usage simmilar (inter)regionally to one superroot
Percentage of related words usage traceable (inter)regionally to one superroot

Because of increased leeway the last categories should be weighted lowly and/or treated carefully.

pod(leg)â‡”bootâ‡”foot
